channel.title: The Christian Science Monitor | World
channel.description: Global news coverage from The Christian Science Monitor.
channel.copyright: Christian Science Monitor. All rights reserved.

item.title: ‘Save this country’: Brazil grapples with trust on heels of Lula victory
item.description: Mistrust in democracy is on full display following incumbent Bolsonaro’s electoral defeat. Can Lula rebuild faith in Brazil?
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova

item.title: Imran Khan is stable after march shooting. Is Pakistan?
item.description: Imran Khan survives attack but inspires little faith in electorate disillusioned by politicians and their ties to the military.
item.dc:creator: Hasan Ali

item.title: Beneath the sands of time, a new Christian discovery in Middle East
item.description: A Christian monastery that possibly pre-dates the spread of Islam has been discovered on an island off the coast of the United Arab Emirates. It’s “a story that deserves to be told,” said Timothy Power, an associate professor of archaeology.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gambrell

item.title: Rising tension: North Korea fires ICBM in latest missile barrage
item.description: On Wednesday, North Korea launched more than 20 missiles in one day, the highest amount in a single day ever. On Thursday, they launched six missiles into the sea, including an intercontinental ballistic missile that caused Japan to issue an evacuation alert.
item.dc:creator: Kim Tong-Hyung and Mari Yamaguchi

item.title: Buoyed by rise of Israeli hard right, Netanyahu heads back to power
item.description: In its fifth election in four years, Israel appears poised to elect former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He’ll be joined by members of the far-right Religious Zionism party, cementing the country’s most right wing government in history.
item.dc:creator: Tia Goldenberg

item.title: How can British Conservatives get on the same page with the public?
item.description: New Prime Minister Rishi Sunak may have brought a calm back to No. 10, but the ruling Conservatives remain out of touch with much of the British public. How do they get back in sync?
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khullar Relph

item.title: After two years, Ethiopia and Tigray make tentative peace
item.description: Ethiopia and Tigray have agreed to a coordinated disarmament during peace talks on Wednesday. The conflict, which lasted two years, led to hundreds of thousands of casualties and millions of people displaced.
item.dc:creator: Mogomotsi Magome and Cara Anna

item.title: On climate change targets, can success be relative?
item.description: Doubts are surfacing over the world’s ability to meet targets to limit global warming, prompting some experts to suggest a more nuanced approach.
item.dc:creator: Ned Temko

item.title: Qatar preps for World Cup, regional respect for women's soccer lags
item.description: In the soccer-obsessed Middle East, women’s teams have been held back by lack of financing and conservative attitudes. Momentum across the region is uneven but active government participation is growing and shifting public attitudes.
item.dc:creator: Lee Keath and Omar Akour

item.title: ‘There are not two Brazils’: Can President-elect Lula bridge deep divides?
item.description: Brazil’s runoff election underscored the country’s deep divides. Despite protests contesting his win, President-elect Lula says his focus will be on unity.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Downie

item.title: Post-hurricane, Canada charts new relationship with the sea
item.description: Canada never experienced a storm as powerful as September’s Hurricane Fiona. Now, Prince Edward Island, like many coastal regions, is rethinking how to coexist with an unpredictable ocean.
item.dc:creator: Moira Donovan

item.title: Fueling up: Free school meals in US and geothermal power in Kenya
item.description: Progress roundup: Governments fuel the dignity of people with wider labor protections, free lunch in more U.S. schools, and the lowering of poverty in China.
item.dc:creator: Erika Page

item.title: South Koreans seek answers to crowd surge, police apologize
item.description: South Korean officials have apologized and accepted responsibility for the October crowd surge that left 156 dead in the country’s worst disaster in years. They have called for innovation in crowd management and support for bereaved family members.
item.dc:creator: Hyung-Jin Kim

item.title: No dirty bombs: UN aims to defuse Russia's claims against Ukraine
item.description: At the request of Kyiv, U.N. experts are investigating Russia’s allegations that Ukraine has placed two “dirty bombs.” These accusations have been made after battlefield setbacks for Russia, and Western nations reject the claim as “transparently false.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Meldrum

item.title: The Kremlin got its 300,000 troops. But how did Russian society fare?
item.description: Russia’s chaotic mobilization of troops has ended, its goals largely met. But the public is still coming to grips with the psychological stresses of the process – and of the ongoing war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Fred Weir

item.title: Lula defeats Bolsonaro in Brazil's tightest elections in decades
item.description: Two decades after first winning the Brazilian presidential elections, Luiz Inácio “Lula” da Silva will return to the presidency to govern a highly polarized nation.
item.dc:creator: Mauricio Saverese and Diane Jeantet

item.title: South Korea responds to fatal Halloween crowd surge
item.description: After the deadliest crushing disaster in South Korean history, support is flowing in while officials investigate the cause of the accident to improve safety standards in other public places.
item.dc:creator: Kim Tong-Hyung and Hyung-Jin Kim

item.title: Russia halts Ukraine grain deal over alleged drone attack on ship
item.description: Russia says one of its ships in Sevastopol was damaged in what it says was a Ukrainian drone attack. Kyiv denied involvement, and claimed that Russian mishandling of its weapons was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Meldrum

item.title: ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’: A German retelling for a modern time
item.description: German filmmaker Edward Berger’s version of “All Quiet on the Western Front” is an effort to help his native country continue its discourse about war and responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Lenora Chu

item.title: As Israel votes (again), Arab union cracks and Jewish right unites
item.description: Cooperation is key to political success, yet alliances can be fragile. In Israel’s fifth election in four years, one successful partnership crumbles even as an anti-democratic union rises.
item.dc:creator: Neri Zilber
